Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Improving Analysis of Microbial Mixtures through Sparse Reconstruction Algorithms and Statistical Inference
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to improve microbial classification and comparison from next-generation sequencing technology. The first objective is to improve microbial identification from short reads, using a Bayesian classifier. While the classifier is fast, it can rely on a large set of features. This is due to its reliance on fixed DNA word sizes that may have many zero-frequencies when the word size is long. The investigators propose to compensate the classifier with a zero-inflated negative binomial and Poisson models, instead of traditionally using linguistic "smoothing" techniques that are ad-hoc at best. The second objective is to reduce the feature size for whole-genome analysis. For long DNA word sizes, there is an enormous feature space, and by using random manifolds, compressive sensing, and other techniques, the investigators propose to reduce the feature space while retaining accuracy of microbial classification. Finally, the third objective is to be able to model and fit functions to microbial population changes in a gradient (a changing environmental factor), especially when many of the data points are missing. This final objective will allow biologists and ecologists to now correlate the microbial composition (from the first two objectives) to environmental factors and to model microbial changes and thus improve future threat detection.

The investigators are developing mathematical methods to model how an environment is uniquely identified by its microbial community. Because a chemical will not have to be measured directly, the projects' results will enable advances in biotechnology for trace chemical detection and forensics. An example is modeling soil microbial community changes in response to buried explosives in order to enhance detection of these devices and secure our troops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made contributions to algorithm development of microbial communities and theoretical math development. Understanding microbial communities is vital to understanding human health and the environment (since there are microbes in and on us and in lush and harsh environments on earth). The major innovations were 1) a technique (and software) to quickly determine the percentage of different organisms in microbiome samples, 2) techniques and software to select important variables that differentiate samples (including a method to automatically determine the number that are important), 3) a software that can decipher microbial patterns/themes that underlie and/or interact with a complex disease (or environmental factor), 4) allowing sparse signal recovery using nonnegative least squares,5) conception and analysis of hard thresholding pursuit algorithms. 
For 1), Quikr (QUadratic, K-mer-based, Iterative, Reconstruction) was designed and implemented in a software package (https://github.com/EESI/quikr) to allow microbiome researchers to quickly derive the composition of microbes in a sample from the 16S rRNA barcode gene.  We show that this method sped up the classification of the Human Microbiome Project data by 10 times.  The method sacrifices each DNA sequence being assigned to quickly determine relative abundances (RAs, or percentages) of the organisms present in a sample.  This is beneficial because most downstream analysis only requires RAs, such as measuring the similarity/distance between samples (ordination). The technique was expanded to also operate on whole-genome shotgun data (https://sourceforge.net/projects/wgsquikr/).  Subsequent techniques have now been developed that have springboarded from this idea (SEK and MetaPalette).
For 2), we developed Fizzy (https://github.com/EESI/Fizzy), which allows users to choose from information-theoretic and L1 methods to select features from metagenomic samples.  The variables of interest can be organisms, genes, functional attributes, or anything that can be “counted” in a microbiome sample.  However, these methods require the user to enter a guess as to how many features they expect to have importance in distinguishing the samples.  NPFS (Neyman-Pearson Feature Selection, https://github.com/EESI/NPFS) was specifically developed under the grant, as a way to automatically select the most relevant features (and removes this requirement).  An early implementation of this idea was used to distinguish between the microbiomes of different age groups, and we discovered that a vitamin B12 biosynthesis pathway was downregulated in persons above mid-age. This was the first study to show this and has been subsequently shown in other studies.
For 3), we developed a way to uncover thematic structure in microbiome studies using topic modeling.  The in-development software (to be released on https://github.com/EESI)  conducts analyses on 16S rRNA barcode genes to identify topics of co-occuring taxa. We can show the functional genes and pathways that compose these topics and how these topics relate to host and environmental factors. This workflow will not only allow users to simultaneously explore taxonomic, functional, and sample information, but will also help identify noteworthy functional gene sets specific to topics of interest, which in turn may offer insight into the microbiomes of complex diseases.
For 4), inspired by our metagenomics studies, we developed a simple way to perform the recovery of sparse vectors acquired via compressive linear measurements. It is easier to implement than standard L1-minimization/LASSO and is surprisingly related to the orthogonal matching pursuit algorithm, while retaining the excellent performances in terms of accuracy and speed. This has far-reaching implications since it can allow fast and faithful recovery in many other applications. 
For 5), we introduced an algorithm called Graded Hard Thresholding Pursuit (GHTP), improving upon the algorithm Hard Thresholding Pursuit (HTP) previously proposed by the PI in the sense that an a priori estimation of the sparsity level is not needed to run the algorithm. It was also shown that, under classical restricted isometry conditions, both HTP and GHTP converge in a finite number of iterations which is at most proportional to the sparsity level.

The grant trained 2 Biostatistics masters student (who went on to work in research at a major university), 4 PhD students (two who went on to work in research at a major university, one who went on to a faculty position, and another who will complete their MD/PhD soon), 2 mathematics Masters students, 2 mathematics postdocs (one in a research position and another one going on to a faculty position), and 1 undergraduate student (now a data scientist for a healthcare company) who taught mathematics labs at the Philadelphia High School for Girls.
